question_content.barrons:question: In giving advice to his son, old Polonius expressed himself only in ___________; every bit of counsel he gave was a truism.
question_content.barrons:explanation:
chestnuts, platitudes.

The key word here is truism. Platitudes are trite remarks or clichés, banal comments uttered as if they were original. Chestnuts are old, timeworn saying or tales. So are truisms.

Supposition is incorrect. The key word here is truism. Suppositions are assumptions or hypotheses. They are not truisms (obvious truths; clichés).

Encomiums is incorrect. The key word here is truism. Encomiums are expressions of praise. They are not truisms (obvious truths; clichés).

Conundrums is incorrect. The key word here is truism. Conundrums are puzzles. They are not truisms (obvious truths; clichés).

Epithets is incorrect. The key word here is truism. Epithets are descriptive words or phrases, often derogatory. They are not truisms (obvious truths; clichés).
